723527f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street
723527f.text:
Broadway, west side, south from 43rd Street, showing also
a view south on Seventh avenue. In the centre 1s the Pabst Hotel.
Withun two years this will be demolished, and the New York Times
Buildin; erected on the site.
1902.
H. N. Tiemann Co.

717492f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717492f-a.text:
Broadway, north from W. 4'rd Street (intersection at
richt foreground) showing the open area formed hv the crossing
f this thorouohfare and Seventh Avernue and known as Times
Square. Prominently seen is the Hotel Aetor. To the left
of same are brownstone structures where the 6 story Putnam
Buildino was later erected. Todav (1938) the huge Paramount
Building occupies this site. Note the sole automobie and
street car. To the right is the Ne York Theatre.
December 1905.
Geo. L. Balgue.

717495f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street
717495f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, from 43rd to 45th Streets. The Hotel Cadillac,
after remodelling, will for a while be called the Wallick, but its
original name will soon be restored. Rector's, a famous restaurant
of the fin du sidcle days, will soon be replaced, along with the
corner u ng a 4th Street, by the Hotel Claridge. In the next
block, from 44th to 45th Streets, is the New York Theatre, which also
houses the Criterion Theatre. This building will be torn down in 1935.
May, 1909.
Brown Brothers.

723530f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street
723530f-a.text:
Broadway, west side, south from and including 43rd Street, show-
ing also the west side of Seventh Avenue, south from 43rd Street.
In the centre is the second building of the New York Times, built in
1904. This building caused the name of the region bounded by Broadway
and Seventh Avenue from 42nd to 47th Streets to be changed from
Longacre Square to Times Square. The Times was formerly located at
41 Park Row, and in the middle 1920's will move to 43rd Street west
of Seventh Avenue.
1909.
Wurts Brothers.
:

717490f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717490f.text:
1493-1505 Broadway, west side, from West 43rd (left) to 44th (right)
Streets, showing the 6-story Putnam Building that today (1937) has been
replaced by the mammonth Paramount Building. Shown on the left and west
of a row of 4-story structures (Nos. 207 to 215 inclusive) is the 4 and
11-story Times Annex. On the right appears a corner of the Hotel Astor.
This area is known as Times Square, though the buildings bear Broadway
hnumbers.
About 1925.
Brown Brothers.
7veg ~ 9e~7

713156f-a.title: Manhattan: 43rd Street (West) - 7th Avenue
713156f-a.text:
241-247 W:est 43rd Street, north side, between Seventh and Eighth
Avenues : an old apartment house called Yandis Court.
June 1O, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717477f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717477f-a.text:
1491-1485 Broadway, at, adjoining and south of the S.W. corner of West
43rd Street. This section of Times Square is technically Seventh Ave., with
Broadway numbers.
July 25, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

717486f-a.text:
The Hotels Cadillac and Claridge, Broadway, east side, from
43rd to 44th Streets.
February 5, 1929.

709798f-a.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - 43rd Street
709798f-a.text:
South on Seventh Avenue, from the Paramount Theatre, at 43rd Street.
About 1929.
Photograph. by Ewing Galloway.

713155f-a.text:

709800f-a.title: Manhattan: 7th Avenue - 43rd Street
709800f-a.text:
Paramount Building and Theatre, Seventh Avenue, west side, from 43rd
to 44th Streets, taken from 145 West 45th Street. In the right
foreground may be seen the Astor Hotel, at the N.W. corner of
44th Street.
Auust 4, 1935.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.

717480f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717480f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), at the N. E. corner of West
43rd Street, showing the Hotel Cadillac prior to demolition
in 1940. At the left is the adjoining Hotel Claridae at
44th Street. In the foreground are the Police Information
Booth and a subway kiosk.
The Hotel Cadillac was erected in two units. The first
to rise was the eight story corner structure. This was built
as the Barrett House in 1883. The adjoining unit rose several
years later.and was the first to bear the name Cadillac. In
1900 they were combined. For a brief period between 1910 and
1915 they were known as the Hotel 7allick. The land upon
which they stand has been owned by the Goelet interests, passing
from Cgden Goelet to his daughter :ay, the wife of the Duke
of Roxburghe, and to her son the present Duke.
For a more complete account see the New York Times of
March 19, 1940.

717488f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717488f-b.text:
(1)
Broadway, east side, north from Wost 43rd to 45th Streets, showing
the 8 and 13-story units of the Hotel Claridge, the Criterion and Loew's
N.Y. Theatre (under demolition), and Loew's State Theatre (N.E. corner
of 45th Street).
July 6, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A closer view of the West 44th to 45th Streets block, preparat ory
to demolition.
June 17, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
The same as No 1,at a later date, sho ing complete demolitiou of the
former building that housed the Criterion and Loew's N.Y. Theatres.
September 21, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

723545f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
723545f-a.text:
Times Square: At West 43rd Street and viewing northward. In the
immediate foreground is an information booth, staffed by the New York
Police Department. This set consists of two similar views.
September 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723545f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
723545f-b.text:
Times Square: At West 43rd Street and viewing northward. In the
immediate foreground is an information booth, staffed by the New York
Police Department. This set consists of two similar views.
September 21, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

723528f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street
723528f-a.text:
Broadway (right) and Seventh Ave. (left), north from but not in-
cluding West 43rd Street, showing Times Square during a drenching
afternoon rain (3 P.M.). Note the automobiles with their headlights
turned on and theatres with their electric signs lighted. This view is
taken from the Times Building and appeared the following day, Tuesday
July 13, 1937, in the New York Times.
July 12, 1937.
Gift of Wide World Photo Inc.

717478f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717478f-b.text:
Broadway (Times Square), at the N. E. corner of W. 43rd Street,
showing the cleared site of the old Hotel Cadillac. At the left
is a portion of the Hotel Claridge. W. 43rd Street is on the right
and the view is eastward on the north side of same. Note the Hotel
Woodstock there. It was outside of this structure that the famous
Becker murder case (Rosenthal) was enacted.
View 1: June 17, 1940
View 2: August 23, 1940
P. L. Sperr

717478f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717478f-a.text:

717494f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - 43rd Street (West)
717494f-a.text:
Broadway (Times Square), east side, south across W. 43rd
Street, showing the changes at the two corners of same. The
former Hotel Cadillac site is being cleared at the N. E. corner.
The two story taxpayer opposite is occupied by Toffenetti's.
This was formerly the site of the Fitzgerald Building and the
George M. Cohan Theatre.
In the background are the towering buildings, No. 1450
Broadway, and the 3ush Terminal.
June 17, 1940
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr
